chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a man with hair loss in primary care?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• For a man presenting with hair loss in primary care, the diagnosis of androgenetic alopecia is usually made from the clinical findings alone.
  • Take a detailed history to assess the severity, impact, and possible causes of hair loss. Ask about the following:
    • Timing and pattern of the hair loss — including onset, speed of progression, and scalp areas affected.
    • Co-morbidities, including systemic disease (such as a recent severe infection) or endocrine disorders (such as hypothyroidism).
    • Family history of alopecia.
    • Use of medication (such as antidepressants, anticoagulants, chemotherapy, anabolic steroids, or carbimazole) and dietary habits (such as excessive dieting). 
    • The normal hair care routine, including changes in hairstyle to compensate for alopecia and the use of any hair care procedures or products.
    • The psychological impact of hair loss and the impact on their quality of life.
  • Assess the pattern and distribution of hair thinning and inspect the scalp.
    • Typically, androgenetic alopecia in men presents with bitemporal recession of the hairline and thinning of the hair of the crown (vertex) and frontal parietal areas. Normal hair may be replaced by short, thin vellus hairs.
    • The degree of hair loss can be assessed using the Hamilton-Norwood Scale.
    • About 10% of men with androgenetic alopecia present with a female pattern of hair loss, which includes thinning in the density of hair at the crown and frontal scalp, and widening of the central parting with retention of the frontal hairline. See the section on the Ludwig Scale in the CKS topic on Alopecia, androgenetic - female for more information. 
  • Consider using the 'pull test' (depending on clinical judgement).
  • Suspect an underlying cause or alternative diagnosis if there is:
    • Profound shedding or a rapid onset of hair loss which may indicate telogen effluvium.
    • Temporal hair thinning which may indicate traction alopecia, frontal fibrosing alopecia, or hypothyroidism.
    • Inflammation, papules or pustules, scaling, or scarring of the scalp.
    • Systemic disease, such as a recent severe infection, iron deficiency, or hypothyroidism.
    • Exposure to or a change of medication.
    • Excessive dietary habits or rapid weight loss.
  • Consider whether any investigations are required.

subChapters.htmlHeader: The Hamilton-Norwood Scale
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The degree of hair loss can be assessed using the Hamilton-Norwood (or Norwood) scale.
    • An illustration of the Hamilton-Norwood scale is provided in an Expert Reviews in Molecular Medicine article.
  • There are seven levels of possible hair loss:
    • Norwood 1 — the man has a normal head of hair with no visible hair loss.
    • Norwood 2 — the hair is receding in a wedge-shaped pattern.
    • Norwood 3 — the man has the same receding pattern as Norwood 2, except the hairline has receded deeper into the frontal area and the temporal area.
    • Norwood 4 — the hairline has receded more dramatically in the frontal region and temporal areas than in Norwood 3, and there is the beginning of a bald spot at the back of the head.
    • Norwood 5 — the hair grows in the same pattern as Norwood 4 but with a much reduced hair density.
    • Norwood 6 — the strip of hair connecting the two sides of the head that existed in Norwood 4 and 5 no longer exists in Norwood 6.
    • Norwood 7 — the man has hair receding all the way back to the base of the head and the sides just above the ears.

[Norwood, 1975; Blume-Peytavi et al, 2010; BMJ, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: The Pull test
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Although the 'pull test' does not provide a definitive diagnosis of androgenetic alopecia, it is a crude tool to determine the ongoing activity and severity of any type of hair loss. 
    • It is usually negative in androgenetic alopecia, except for affected areas of the scalp, where a moderate degree of telogen hair shedding may occur during active periods of the disease.
    • A diffusely positive pull test requires investigation for telogen effluvium (but androgenetic alopecia may still coexist).
    • The test is of value only in experienced hands, as it shows high inter-observer variation and is influenced by hair shampooing and washing. Examiners should standardize their own procedure. 
  • The 'pull test' technique:
    • Tug a bundle of approximately 50–100 hairs firmly, but not forcibly, away from the scalp, sliding the fingers along the hair shaft. 
    • The test is positive if more than 3 hairs are pulled away from the scalp (although up to 10% of grasped hairs may come off) and indicates active hair shedding.

[Blume-Peytavi et al, 2010; BMJ, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The recommendations on how to diagnose and assess androgenetic alopecia in men are based on expert opinion in a European consensus guideline on the diagnostic evaluation of androgenetic alopecia in men, women, and adolescents [Blume-Peytavi et al, 2010], review articles on the diagnosis and management of androgenetic alopecia [Hillman and Blume-Peytavi, 2009; Shamsaldeen et al, 2013; Piraccini and Alessandrini, 2014], and the British Medical Journal (BMJ) Best practice review article on androgenetic alopecia [BMJ, 2015].
